hints.content:
###Background 

An $m\times n$ matrix has $m$ rows and $n$ columns. 

>$A=\left[\begin{array}{rr}A_{1,1} & \cdots & A_{1,n}
\\\\\vdots \ & \ddots & \vdots 
\\\\A_{m,1} &\cdots &A_{m,n}\end{array}\right]$ 

Therefore, the entry $A_{\blueD{c},\maroonD{d}}$ is located on row $\blueD{c}$ and column $\maroonD{d}$.

###Finding $A_{4,1}$

$A_{\blueD{4},\maroonD{1}}$ is located on row $\blueD{4}$ of $A$:

>$\left[\begin{array}{rr}-3 & 3 & -6 & 5 & 8
\\12 & 35 & 13 & 14 & 2
\\-6 &8 & 9 & -18 & 1
\\\blueD{-5} & \blueD{-3} & \blueD{-23} & \blueD{6} & \blueD{4}
\\4 &-5 &15 & 3 & 10\end{array}\right]$ 

$A_{\blueD{4},\maroonD{1}}$ is also located on column $\maroonD{1}$ of $A$. 

>$\left[\begin{array}{rr}\maroonD{-3} & 3 & -6 & 5 & 8
\\\maroonD{12} & 35 & 13 & 14 & 2
\\\maroonD{-6} &8 & 9 & -18 & 1
\\\maroonD{\text{-5}} & \blueD{-3} & \blueD{-23} & \blueD{6} & \blueD{4}
\\\maroonD{4} &-5 &15 & 3 & 10\end{array}\right]$ 

Therefore, $A_{\blueD{4},\maroonD{1}}=\maroonD{-5}$.

###Background 

We can express a system of equations in  an *augmented matrix* in which each row represents one equation. To do this, we write the coefficients of each variable in its own column, and the constants on the right side of the equations in the last column.

For example, if we are given a system of equations in two variables, then we can express this as an augmented matrix as follows. 

>$\begin{align}ax+by&=m
\\cx+dy&=n\end{align}$  $\qquad \rightarrow$ $\qquad \left[\begin{array} {ccc}
a & b & m \\
c & d & n \end{array} \right]$

###Representing the system of equations as a matrix

We are given the system of equations: 

>$\begin{align}x+5y=24
\\x-8y=-41\end{align}$

First, let's rewrite this system to show the coefficients of each variable. 

>$\begin{align}\blueD{1}x+\blueD{5}y&=\blueD{24}
\\\blueD{1}x+(\blueD{-8})y&=\blueD{-41}\end{align}$

Now, we can write our augmented matrix.


>$\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
1 & 5 & 24 \\
1 & -8 & -41 \end{array} \right]\\$

###Summary

Our augmented matrix is: 

>$\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
1 & 5 & 24 \\
1 & -8 & -41 \end{array} \right]\\$

###Background 

There are three basic row operations that can be performed on matrices. 

- $R_i \leftrightarrow R_j$. This symbol tells us to interchange rows $i$ and $j$. 
- $cR_i \rightarrow R_i$. This symbol tells us to multiply a row $i$ by a constant $c$. 
- $R_i + cR_j \rightarrow R_i$. This symbol tells us to add $c$ times row $j$ to row $i$.

###Substituting the row 

Now, we must substitute row $R_3$ with $9R_3$. 

$\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
-5 & -7 & 8 & 5 \\
1 & 2 & -3 & 2 \\
\tealD{1} & \tealD{0} & \tealD{0} & \tealD{-1} \end{array} \right]  \xrightarrow{9R_3\rightarrow R_3} \left[\begin{array} {ccc}
-5 & -7 & 8 & 5 \\
1 & 2 & -3 & 2 \\
\tealD{9} & \tealD{0} & \tealD{0} & \tealD{-9} \end{array} \right] $

###Summary 

Our resultant matrix is the following. 

$\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
-5 & -7 & 8 & 5 \\
1 & 2 & -3 & 2 \\
9 & 0 & 0 & -9 \end{array} \right]$

###The Strategy 

To add or subtract matrices that have the same dimensions, we add or subtract the corresponding terms from each matrix that have the same coordinates. [[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
When we add or subtract two $m \times n$ matrices, $A$ and $B$, we get a new matrix $C$ that is also $m \times n$. 

Each of $C$'s entries equals the sum or difference of the corresponding entries of $A$ and $B$ that have the same coordinates. 

That is, for any row $c$ and column $d$, we have $C_{c,d}=A_{c,d}+B_{c,d}$. 

For example, if we are subtracting two $2 \times 2$ matrices, $A$ and $B$: 

$\begin{align}C&=A-B
\\&=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \blueE{A_{1,1}} & \greenE{A_{1,2}}
\\ \goldD{A_{2,1}} & \maroonC{A_{2,2}} \end{array}\right] -\left[\begin{array}{rr} \blueE{B_{1,1}} & \greenE{B_{1,2}}
\\ \goldD{B_{2,1}} & \maroonC{B_{2,2}} \end{array}\right]
\\\\&=\left[\begin{array}{rr} (\blueE{A_{1,1}-B_{1,1}}) & (\greenE{A_{1,2}-B_{1,2}})
\\ (\goldD{A_{2,1}-B_{2,1}}) & (\maroonC{A_{2,2}-B_{2,2}})\end{array}\right]
\\\\&=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \blueE{C_{1,1}} & \greenE{C_{1,2}}
\\ \goldD{C_{2,1}} & \maroonC{C_{2,2}} \end{array}\right] 
\\
\\\end{align} $

###The Strategy 

First, we can represent the matrices of the equation with letters, which will make the equation easier to handle.

Then we can solve the equation for $X$ and obtain an expression with the letters we defined.

Finally, we can substitute back the actual matrices into the resulting expression and simplify it.

### Solving the equation for $X$

We are given the following equation. 

$X+\left[\begin{array}{rr} 20 & 10 
\\ -12 & 3
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 23 & 16
\\ 24 & 11\end{array}\right] $ 

Let's represent the above matrices as follows. 

$A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 20 & 10 
\\ -12 & 3
\end{array}\right] ~~~~~~~~~ B = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 23 & 16
\\ 24 & 11\end{array}\right] $ 

Then we can rewrite the equation as follows. 

>$X+A=B$

Now it's simple to solve the equation for $X$.

>$\begin{align}X+A&=B\\\\
X&=B-A
\end{align}$

### Finding $X$

We found that $X=B-A$. Now we can substitute the actual matrices back into the expression and simplify.

$\begin{align}X&=B-A
\\\\&=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 23 & 16
\\ 24 & 11\end{array}\right] -\left[\begin{array}{rr} 20 & 10 
\\ -12 & 3
\end{array}\right]
\\\\\\&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}(23-20) & (16-10) 
\\ (24+12) & (11-3) \end{array}\right]
\\\\\\&=\left[\begin{array}{rr}3 & 6
\\ 36 & 8\end{array}\right]\end{align}$

###Summary 

$X=\left[\begin{array}{rr}3 & 6
\\ 36 & 8\end{array}\right]$

###The Strategy 

When multiplying matrices, we should find each entry of the resulting product matrix separately.

To find entry $(i,j)$ of the resulting product matrix, we calculate the vector *dot product* of row $i$ of the first matrix and column $j$ of the second matrix. [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
In general, vector dot product is an operation that takes two vectors of equal dimensions and returns a single real number.

For any two $n$-dimensional vectors, $\vec{v}=(v_1, v_2, ..., v_n)$ and $\vec{u}=(u_1, u_2, ..., u_n)$, their dot product $\vec{v}\cdot\vec{u}$ is defined as follows.

>$\vec{v}\cdot\vec{u}=v_1\cdot u_1+v_2\cdot u_2 +...+v_n\cdot u_n$

For example, for $\vec{v}=(a,b)$ and $\vec{u}=(c,d)$, we have $\vec{v}\cdot\vec{u}=a\cdot c+b\cdot d$.

### The strategy

- Analyze the effect of $\text{T}$ on the unit vectors, using the fact that a general transformation matrix $\left[ \begin{array}{cc} \greenC{a} & \redC{b} \\ \greenC{c} & \redC{d} \end{array} \right]$ takes the unit vector $\left[ \begin{array}{cc}  \greenC{1} \\ \greenC{0}  \end{array} \right]$ to $\left[ \begin{array}{cc}  \greenC{a} \\ \greenC{c}  \end{array} \right]$ and the unit vector $\left[ \begin{array}{cc}  \redC{0} \\ \redC{1}  \end{array} \right]$ to $\left[ \begin{array}{cc}  \redC{b} \\ \redC{d}  \end{array} \right]$.

- Conclude, from the effect $\text{T}$ has on the unit vectors, what its effect would be on any vector.

###Analyzing the effect of $\text{T}$ on the unit vectors

$\text{T} = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} \greenC{-1} & \redC{0} \\ \greenC{0} & \redC{1} \end{array} \right]$ transforms the units vectors as follows.

- $\left[ \begin{array}{cc}  \greenC{1} \\ \greenC{0}  \end{array} \right] \rightarrow \left[ \begin{array}{cc}  \greenC{-1} \\ \greenC{0}  \end{array} \right]$

- $\left[ \begin{array}{cc}  \redC{0} \\ \redC{1}  \end{array} \right]\rightarrow\left[ \begin{array}{cc}  \redC{0} \\ \redC{1 } \end{array} \right]$ 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3ce44076f18470240ad592ee77380f08e7383262)

### Analyzing the general effect of $\text{T}$

We can describe this effect of $\text{T}$ on the unit vectors as follows: **the $x$-vector is reversed in direction (relative to the origin), but both vectors' distances (from the origin) remain the same.**

This is the effect $\text{T}$ will have on any vector. In other words, **$\text{T}$ is a reflection about the $y$-axis.**

### Conclusion

The only option that represents a reflection across the $y$-axis  is $D$, so this is the correct answer.

###The Strategy 

When two matricies are inverses, their product (in either order) equals the identity matrix, $I$. 

Therefore, we must check to see if $AB=I$.

###Finding $AB$ 

$\begin{align}AB&=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 & -1
\\ -1 & 9 \end{array}\right]
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \dfrac{9}{26} & \dfrac{1}{26}
\\\\ \dfrac{1}{26} & \dfrac{3}{26} \end{array}\right]
\\\\&=\left[\begin{array}{rr} (3\cdot\dfrac{9}{26}-1\cdot\dfrac{1}{26}) & (3\cdot\dfrac{1}{26}-1\cdot\dfrac{3}{26})
\\\\(-1\cdot\dfrac{9}{26}+9\cdot\dfrac{1}{26}) & (-1\cdot\dfrac{1}{26}+9\cdot\dfrac{3}{26})\end{array}\right]
\\\\\\&=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 & 0
\\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right]
\\\\&=I\end{align}$ 

Since the product $AB$ gives us the identity matrix, $A$ and $B$ are inverses.

###Summary 

Yes, $A$ and $B$ are inverses.

A square matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant does not equal zero. Therefore, all we need to do is to take the determinant of $A$ and check if it equals zero. 

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
If we are given the following $2 \times 2$ matrix, $C$: 

$C=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \blueD{a} & \maroonD{b}
\\ \maroonD{c} & \blueD{d} \end{array}\right] $ 

We can find the determinant of $C$ using the following formula: 

$\det{C}=\blueD{ad}-\maroonD{bc}$

hints.content:
###Summary 

Since $\det{A}\neq0$, $A$ is invertible.

hints.content:
###The Strategy 

To find the inverse of an invertible matrix, we can use *Gaussian Elimination*. To do this, we do the following. 

- First, we append the matrix $\text B$ with the identity matrix $\text I$ to get $\left[\begin{array} ~\text B ~ |~\text I\end{array}\right]$. 

- Next, we use Gaussian Elimination to reduce $\text B$ to the identity matrix, $\text I$. Performing the same operations on $\text I$ will convert it to $\text B^{-1}$, so that our new matrix becomes $\left[\begin{array} ~\text I ~ |~\text B^{-1}\end{array}\right]$.

###Appending $\text B$ with $\text I$

$\left[\begin{array} ~\text B ~ |~\text I\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{rr}-9 & -6 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right]$

###Eliminating the leading term in the second row

We want the first term of $R_2$ to equal $0$, but since it already is, we don't need to subtract a multiple of $R_1$ from $R_2$ in our first step.

###Reducing the leading terms and back-solving 

Now, let's reduce the leading term of $R_2$ to equal $1$. 

$\left[\begin{array}{rr}-9 & -6 & 1 & 0 \\ \tealD{0} & \tealD{2} & \tealD{0} & \tealD{1} \end{array}\right]\xrightarrow{\dfrac{1}{2}R_2\rightarrow R_2}\left[\begin{array}{rr}-9 & -6 & 1 & 0 \\ \tealD{0} & \tealD{1} & \tealD{0} & \tealD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{array}\right]$ 

We are ready to back-solve to get $\left[\begin{array} ~\text I ~ |~\text B^{-1}\end{array}\right]$. 

$\begin{align}\!\!\left[\begin{array}{rr}\!\tealD{-9}\! & \tealD{-6}\! & \tealD{1}\! & \tealD{0} \\ \!0\! & 1\! & 0\! &\dfrac{1}{2} \!\end{array}\right]\!\xrightarrow{\!\!R_1+6R_2\rightarrow R_1\!\!}
\!\!&\left[\begin{array}{rr}\!\tealD{\!-9}\!\! & \tealD{0}\!\! & \tealD{1} \!\!& \tealD{3} \!\\ \!0\! & 1\! & 0\! &\dfrac{1}{2}  \end{array}\right]
\!\!\xrightarrow{\!\!\large{-}\dfrac{1}{9}R_1\!\rightarrow R_1\!\!}\!\!\left[\begin{array}{rr}\tealD{1}\!\! & \tealD{0}\!\! & \tealD{-\!\dfrac{1}{9}}\!\! & \tealD{-\!\dfrac{1}{3}} \\ \!0\! & 1\! & 0\! &\dfrac{1}{2}  \end{array}\right]\end{align}$ 

Therefore $\text B^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{rr} -\dfrac{1}{9}\!\! & -\dfrac{1}{3} \\ 0 \!\!& \dfrac{1}{2} \end{array}\right]$.

###Summary 

$\text B^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{rr} -\dfrac{1}{9}\!\! & -\dfrac{1}{3} \\ 0 \!\!& \dfrac{1}{2} \end{array}\right]$

question.content:
**Find the inverse of the matrix, $\text B =  \left[\begin{array}{rr}-9 & -6 \\ 0 & 2 \end{array}\right]$.** 

 
[[☃ matrix 1]]

hints.content:
###The Strategy 

A system of equations can be represented by a matrix equation $\text{A}\vec{x}=\vec{b}$, where

- $\text{A}$ is the *coefficient matrix*,
- $\vec{x}$ is the *variables vector*, and
- $\vec{b}$ is the *constants vector*.

Each row of the matrix equation represents an equation in the system. [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Let's consider the following system of equations. 

>$\begin{align}a_1x+b_1y+c_1z&=k_1
\\a_2x+b_2y+c_2z&=k_2
\\a_3x+b_3y+c_3z&=k_3\end{align}$ 

We see that if we multiply the row vector, 
$\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
a_1 & b_1 & c_1 \end{array} \right] $, by the column vector, $\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
x\\
y \\ 
z \end{array} \right]$, we get the first equation. 

>$\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
a_1 & b_1 & c_1 \end{array} \right] \left[\begin{array} {ccc}
x\\
y \\ 
z \end{array} \right]= a_1x+b_1y+c_1z=k_1$

Similarly, if we do the same for the second and third equations, we can write a matrix to express all three equations which describe the full system. This is matrix equation is written below. 

$\qquad \left[\begin{array} {ccc}
a_1 & b_1 & c_1 \\
a_2 & b_2 & c_2 \\ 
a_3 & b_3 & c_3 \end{array} \right]
\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
x\\
y \\ 
z \end{array} \right]=
\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
k_1\\
k_2 \\ 
k_3 \end{array} \right]$

hints.content:
###Representing the system of equations as a matrix equation

We are given the system of equations: 

>$\begin{align}10x+11y-12z&=-18
\\6x-8y-2z&=10
\\4x-6y-8z&=12\end{align}$


First, let's rewrite this system to show the coefficients of each variable. 

>$\begin{align}\tealD{10}x+\tealD{11}y+(\tealD{-12})z&=-18
\\\tealD{6}x+(\tealD{-8})y+(\tealD{-2})z&=10
\\\tealD{4}x+(\tealD{-6})y+(\tealD{-8})z&=12\end{align}$ 

Now, the coefficient matrix can be written as follows. 

>$\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
\tealD{10} & \tealD{11} & \tealD{-12} \\
\tealD{6} & \tealD{-8} & \tealD{-2} \\
\tealD{4} & \tealD{-6} & \tealD{-8} \end{array} \right]\\$ 


We can multiply this matrix by a column vector of variables and set it equal to a column vector with the values on the right side of the equations, as follows.

>$\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
\tealD{10} & \tealD{11} & \tealD{-12} \\
\tealD{6} & \tealD{-8} & \tealD{-2} \\
\tealD{4} & \tealD{-6} & \tealD{-8} \end{array} \right]\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
x \\
y \\
z \end{array} \right]
=\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
-18 \\
10 \\
12 \end{array} \right]$ 

This is our matrix equation.

###Summary 

$\text{A}$ and $\vec{b}$ are shown below. 

>$\text{A}=\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
10 & 11 & -12 \\
6 & -8 & -2 \\
4 & -6 & -8 \end{array} \right]~~~~~~~~~~~~
\vec{b}=\left[\begin{array} {ccc}
-18 \\
10 \\
12  \end{array} \right]$
